section.title: Reported speech
section.sectiontitle: Use 'reported' or 'indirect' speech to tell people what somebody said. Make the tense of the verb one 'step' further back into the past e.g. the Present Simple changes to the Past Simple and the Past Simple changes to the Past Perfect.
section.text1a: She said (that) she wanted to go out.
section.text2a: He said (that) he had lived there for five years.
section.sectiontitle2: Modal verbs also change e.g. can becomes could and will becomes would.
section.text3: 'Can you help me paint the kitchen?'
section.text3a: She asked me if I could help her paint the kitchen.
section.text4a: He said (that) he would meet me outside the bank.

section.title: Reported speech
section.sectiontitle: In reported speech, subject and object pronouns, references to times and word order can change.
section.text1a: He said he would give it to me the next day.
section.text2a: He asked me what we were doing at the weekend.
section.text3a: He asked me if I had enjoyed the film.
section.text4a: She asked me whether I was a vegetarian.

section.title: Reported speech
section.sectiontitle: Reporting verbs follow fixed patterns. Say and explain are followed by a that clause, tell is followed by an object and a that clause.
section.text1a: She explained that John was ill and couldn't come.
section.text2a: He told us (that) we needed to show identification.
section.sectiontitle2: Ask, remind and warn are followed by an object and an infinitive verb.
section.text4a: We reminded him to post the letter.

section.title: Reported speech
section.sectiontitle: Promise and decide are followed by an infinitive verb.
section.text1a: She promised to give us a full refund.
section.text2a: We decided to stay at home and watch TV.
